{
  "article_text": [
    "coxeter groups are defined by a finite set @xmath1 of generating involutions which are subject to braid relations of the form @xmath2 where both sides have length @xmath3 .",
    "these integers are gathered in a coxeter matrix @xmath4 indexed by @xmath1 .",
    "this abstract presentation hides the fact that coxeter groups occur naturally in a number of algebraic and geometric settings .",
    "they arise frequently as generalized reflection groups , and as a matter of fact coincide with groups generated by orthogonal reflections in the finite case .",
    "the interest in coxeter groups also comes via hecke algebras , which are one - parameter deformations of their group algebras .",
    "these hecke algebras have natural bases indexed by elements of @xmath0 .",
    "coxeter groups possess rich combinatorics , starting in the finite case which includes the symmetric groups for instance .",
    "a lot of the combinatorial structure is encoded in the _ reduced expressions _",
    "an element @xmath5 , which are words @xmath6 in @xmath1 representing @xmath7 such that @xmath7 can not be written with less than @xmath8 generators .",
    "this integer @xmath8 is the _ length _ @xmath9 .",
    "properties of reduced expressions and length form arguably the core of the combinatorics of coxeter groups , for which the standard reference is bjrner and brenti s book  @xcite .",
    "an element of @xmath0 is called _ fully commutative _ ( fc ) if any two of its reduced decompositions can be linked by a series of commutation relations of adjacent letters .",
    "note that for a general element @xmath7 , it is known that any two of its reduced decompositions are linked by braid relations ( matsumoto s property ) . from this point of view , the reduced expressions of a given fc element are thus better behaved . in his seminal work",
    "@xcite , stembridge shows a number of natural characterizations of fc elements ; for instance , their reduced expressions correspond bijectively to linear orderings of a partial order . in the simply laced case , _",
    "i.e. _ when @xmath10 for all @xmath11 , fan and stembridge  @xcite give further characterizations of fc elements in terms of the root system attached to @xmath0 .    the temperley ",
    "lieb algebra is a famous diagram algebra born in statistical mechanics  @xcite , which was later recognized as a quotient of the hecke algebra of type @xmath12  @xcite .",
    "this was later used to define generalized temperley ",
    "lieb algebras for all coxeter groups as quotients of hecke algebras , and then prove that fc elements index a basis of these algebras  @xcite",
    ". we will give applications of our results to the growth of these algebras at the end of this introduction , results that we now proceed to state .",
    "we investigate in this work the enumeration of fc elements in a general coxeter group .",
    "let us first note that there may be a finite number of fc elements even though @xmath0 is infinite : in fact in his work  @xcite , stembridge precisely classifies when this happens , and in a subsequent paper  @xcite he enumerates the number of fc elements in all such cases . to extend these results to general coxeter groups ,",
    "it is natural to enumerate elements according to their length .",
    "we write @xmath13 for the set of all fc elements of length @xmath8 , and let @xmath14 be the corresponding generating function .",
    "it was computed in affine type @xmath15 in  @xcite , and this was recently extended to all finite and affine coxeter groups in  @xcite .    our first contribution deals with the nature of the generating function @xmath16 .",
    "the following result shows that it is essentially in the simplest possible class .",
    "[ th : rationality ] for any coxeter group @xmath0 , the series @xmath16 is rational .",
    "an equivalent formulation is that the sequence @xmath17 satisfies a linear recurrence with constant coefficients for @xmath8 large enough .",
    "there are a number of results studying this enumeration for various subsets of @xmath0 .",
    "first and foremost , the length generating function of @xmath0 itself is rational .",
    "this is classically shown by induction using elementary combinatorics of coxeter groups , see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 7.1 ) or ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 5.12 ) .",
    "a lesser known result is that this is true for the set of reflections of @xmath0 , which are the conjugates of generators @xmath1  @xcite .",
    "another ( simpler ) example is that elements possessing a unique reduced expression also have a rational generating function  @xcite .",
    "the proof of theorem  [ th : rationality ] is not direct ; unlike in the case of @xmath0 , there does not seem to be a simple recursive decomposition of @xmath18 which behaves well with respect to length .",
    "instead , we will use the theory of _",
    "finite automata_. in section  [ sec : rationality ] , we will design an automaton recognizing a language with generating function @xmath16 , which automatically entails rationality .",
    "we start by showing that the set @xmath19 of reduced expressions of elements of @xmath18 is recognized by an explicit automaton @xmath20 .",
    "the design of this automaton and proof of its correctness form the core of section  [ sec : rationality ] .",
    "this recalls here also a celebrated result of brink and howlett  @xcite ( see also  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 4.8 ) ) who show that the set of reduced expressions of _ all _ elements can be recognized by a finite automaton . to go from expressions to elements",
    ", we use the lexicographical order to select normal forms for elements of @xmath18 ; theorem",
    "[ th : rationality ] follows then thanks to a result of anisimov and knuth .",
    "the proof we sketched is completely constructive , and allowed us to implement the computation of @xmath16 given a coxeter group @xmath0 .",
    "we now describe our second contribution . as mentioned above ,",
    "one of the main results of  @xcite is the classification of @xmath0 such that @xmath18 is finite ; let us say that @xmath0 is fc - finite in this case .",
    "now the main contribution of  @xcite is that for any irreducible , affine coxeter group @xmath0 , the sequence @xmath21 is ultimately periodic .",
    "it is then a natural question to wonder if this holds for other coxeter groups , a question we answer in the following theorem .",
    "[ th : classification_intro ] let @xmath0 be an irreducible coxeter group .",
    "the sequence @xmath22 is ultimately periodic if and only if @xmath0 is either fc - finite , an affine coxeter group or has one of the two types    in all other cases , @xmath22 grows exponentially fast .",
    "the coxeter groups listed in theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] are given by their coxeter graph in figure  [ fig : fc_periodic_graphs ] .",
    "we note that both @xmath23 and @xmath24 occur as hyperbolic coxeter groups , as compact and paracompact examples respectively  @xcite .",
    "theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] is proved in section  [ sec : classification ] , where it will appear again as theorem  [ th : classification ] .",
    "the proof goes as follows : first , we check that all groups from the list have an ultimately periodic sequence . to prove that all other groups have exponential growth , we first identify which are the minimal ones according to a certain order on coxeter groups which is compatible with the length of fc elements . then for each of these minimal types",
    ", we either identify a subfamily of fc elements which grows exponentially fast , or resort to theorem  [ th : rationality ] and its implementation to obtain the explicit function @xmath16 .",
    "* growth of generalized temperley ",
    "lieb algebras *    for @xmath0 a coxeter group with coxeter matrix @xmath25 and @xmath26 a unital commutative ring , the associated _ hecke algebra _",
    "@xmath27 is the @xmath26-algebra given by generators @xmath28 and subject to the relations @xmath29 , and @xmath30_{m_{st } } } = { [ t_tt_st_t\\cdots]_{m_{st}}}\\quad\\text{if } m_{st}<+\\infty.$ ] here @xmath31 ; if @xmath32 we get the group algebra of @xmath0 .",
    "for any @xmath5 , define @xmath33 by picking any reduced decomposition @xmath34 for @xmath7 and setting @xmath35 .",
    "these elements @xmath36 then form a basis of @xmath37 ( see for instance  @xcite ) .    the _ generalized temperley ",
    "lieb algebra _",
    "@xmath38 is defined as @xmath39 , where @xmath40 is the ideal generated by the elements @xmath41 where @xmath42 and @xmath43 is the finite dihedral subgroup generated by @xmath44 and @xmath45 .",
    "let @xmath46 be the image of @xmath36 in @xmath38 .",
    "the elements @xmath46 for @xmath47 form a basis of @xmath38 .",
    "consider now the natural filtration @xmath48 of @xmath38 , where @xmath49 is the linear span in @xmath38 of all products @xmath50 with @xmath51 .",
    "a linear basis for @xmath49 is given by the @xmath46 where @xmath52 satisfies @xmath53 .",
    "let the _ growth _ of @xmath38",
    "be @xmath54 the definition depends on the choice of generators , however it makes sense to speak of an exponential growth , or a polynomial growth of degree @xmath55 without specifying the choice of generators .",
    "we refer to  @xcite for more informations on growth of algebras .",
    "the following theorem is a translation of theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] in terms of temperley",
    " lieb algebras .",
    "it generalizes to all coxeter systems @xmath56 the results of  @xcite and  @xcite which dealt with the simply - laced system and the rank @xmath57 case respectively .",
    "the families @xmath58 and @xmath59 are given in figure  [ fig : fc_periodic_graphs ] .",
    "[ th : growthtl ] let @xmath56 be an irreducible coxeter system .",
    "+ @xmath60 if @xmath0 is in @xmath61 , the algebra @xmath38 is finite dimensional .",
    "+ @xmath60 if @xmath0 is in @xmath62 , the algebra @xmath38 has _ linear growth_. + @xmath60 in all other cases , the algebra @xmath38 has _",
    "exponential growth_.    the _ gelfand - kirillov dimension _ of a finitely generated algebra @xmath63 with growth function @xmath64 can be defined as @xmath65 when @xmath8 tends to infinity , where @xmath64 can be computed with respect to any choice of generators . in the three cases distinguished by theorem  [ th : growthtl ] ,",
    "the gelfand - kirillov dimension of @xmath38 is thus @xmath66 or @xmath67 respectively .    to interpret theorem  [",
    "th : rationality ] , it is slightly more pleasant to work with the _ nil temperley ",
    "lieb algebra _",
    "@xmath68 : this is the graded algebra associated with the above filtration of @xmath38 . by definition , this means that its @xmath8th graded component is given by the free module @xmath69 , and the multiplication is inherited from @xmath38 .",
    "these algebras seem to have been studied only in type @xmath70  @xcite and @xmath71  @xcite .",
    "the @xmath8th graded component of @xmath68 has a basis @xmath72 indexed by fc element of length @xmath73 , so its hilbert series is @xmath16 , so that we obtain the following reformulation of theorem  [ th : rationality ] .",
    "[ th : ntlrational ] for any coxeter group @xmath0 , the hilbert series of @xmath68 is rational .",
    "this article is structured as follows . in section  [ sec : coxeter_fullycom ] we give necessary definitions about coxeter groups and fully commutative elements .",
    "section  [ sec : rationality ] is devoted to the proof of theorem  [ th : rationality ] .",
    "the key result is that the reduced expressions of fc elements form a regular language , see theorem  [ th : reducedfcregular ] .",
    "the proof of theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] is the content of section  [ sec : classification ] , and we conclude with some perspectives in section  [ sec : perspectives ] .",
    "let @xmath1 be a finite set , and @xmath25 a symmetric matrix satisfying @xmath74 and @xmath75 .",

    "we call _ braid factors _ the two alternating words in @xmath81 of length @xmath82 . in the special case @xmath83",
    "we have a _",
    "commutation relation_.    a coxeter group is encoded by its associated _ coxeter graph _ @xmath84 , which has vertex set @xmath1 , edges @xmath81 if @xmath85 with edge labels @xmath82 if @xmath86 .",
    "the group @xmath0 is called _ irreducible _ if @xmath84 is connected .",

    "let @xmath56 be a coxeter system .",
    "the _ length _ @xmath9 of an element @xmath5 is the smallest integer @xmath8 such that @xmath96 for some @xmath97 .",
    "such minimal words representing @xmath7 are called _ reduced expressions _ for @xmath7 , and form together the set @xmath98 . for any subset @xmath99 , define the two generating functions @xmath100    these notions can be illustrated with the _ cayley graph _ of @xmath0 with respect to the generators @xmath1 : this is the graph with vertex set @xmath0 and edges @xmath101 .",
    "then @xmath9 is the graph distance from the identity to @xmath7 , and reduced words correspond to paths realizing this distance .",
    "the series @xmath102 and @xmath103 correspond respectively to the _ spherical _ and _ geodesic _ growth series of the subset @xmath63 .",
    "we finally record a fundamental property of reduced expressions .    [",
    "prop : matsumoto ] given two words in @xmath98 , one can always go from one to the other by using only braid relations .",
    "given a graph @xmath104 with vertex set @xmath1 , a @xmath104-commutation class is an equivalence class of words in @xmath105 under the equivalence relation generated by the commutation relations @xmath106 if @xmath81 is not an edge of @xmath107 .",
    "we write @xmath108 for the commutation class of @xmath109 .",
    "[ defi : fullycomm ] an element @xmath5 of a coxeter group is fully commutative ( fc in short ) if @xmath98 is a @xmath110-commutation class .",
    "the set of fc elements of @xmath0 will be denoted by @xmath18 .",
    "an element is fc if one can always go from one reduced expression to another by using only commutation relations . in comparison ,",
    "proposition  [ prop : matsumoto ] says that if all braid relations are allowed , then all elements of @xmath0 have this property .    by a result of stembridge ( * ? ? ?",
    "2.1 ) , if @xmath7 is fc then no word in @xmath98 contains a braid word .",
    "therefore fc elements are in bijective correspondence with commutation classes @xmath111 of reduced words such that no element of @xmath111 contains a braid factor .",
    "it is in fact particularly simple to check that expressions are reduced in this case , as the following lemma shows .",
    "[ lem : fccommclasses ] the map @xmath112 restricts to a bijection between fc elements and commutation classes @xmath111 such that no element in @xmath111 has a braid factor @xmath113_{m_{st}}}$ ] for a @xmath85 or a square @xmath114 .",
    "we must show that such a commutation class @xmath111 is formed of reduced words .",
    "now by tits result  @xcite , any word representing @xmath5 can be transformed into a reduced word by a series of braid relations and deletions of squares @xmath114 .",
    "but there are no braid relations to apply in any word of @xmath111 , so these are indeed reduced .      to deal nicely with commutation classes",
    ", we will use the concept of _ heaps _ as developed by viennot  @xcite .",
    "we use the definition given in @xcite .",
    "let @xmath107 be a finite graph with vextex set @xmath115 and edge set @xmath116 .",
    "a _ heap _ on @xmath104 is a poset @xmath117 together with labels @xmath118 such that ( a ) if @xmath119 , the set @xmath120 of elements of @xmath121 with labels in @xmath81 form a chain , and ( b ) the order @xmath122 is the transitive closure of the union of all chains above .",
    "more explicitly , ( b ) amounts to saying that @xmath123 in @xmath121 only if there exists a chain @xmath124 in which @xmath125 for any @xmath126 .",
    "since @xmath120 is linearly ordered , it can be encoded with the word in @xmath127 formed by the labels of @xmath120 in increasing order .",
    "we shall in fact consider heaps up to isomorphism : @xmath121 and @xmath128 are isomorphic if there exists a poset isomorphism from @xmath121 to @xmath128 which preserves labels .    .",
    "the heaps are represented by their defining chains , oriented from bottom to top.[fig : heaps ] ]    there is a function @xmath129 between words and @xmath104-heaps , defined as follows .",
    "let @xmath130 .",
    "define a partial ordering @xmath131 of @xmath132 as follows : set @xmath123 if @xmath133 and @xmath134 is an edge of @xmath104 , and extend to a partial order by transitivity .",
    "we get a heap @xmath135 by naturally labeling @xmath136 by @xmath137 .",
    "for instance , words @xmath138 and @xmath139 give rise to heaps @xmath140 and @xmath141 of figure  [ fig : heaps ] respectively .",
    "the fundamental property is that _",
    "@xmath142 is a bijection between @xmath104-commutation classes and @xmath104-heaps_. the inverse bijection is obtained by considering all linear extensions of @xmath121 and reading the words formed by the labels .",
    "now assume @xmath143 is the coxeter graph of @xmath56 , so that @xmath144 . by lemma  [ lem : fccommclasses ] ,",
    "fc elements are in bijection with certain @xmath104-commutation classes ; it is natural to try to characterize the corresponding heaps .",
    "consider the following two properties of a @xmath104-heap @xmath121 :    ( h1 ) @xmath121 contains no covering relation @xmath123 with @xmath145 .",
    "( h2 ) @xmath121 contains no convex chain @xmath146 with alternating labels @xmath147 for @xmath148 . here",
    "@xmath149 is convex if whenever @xmath150 , we have that @xmath151 imply @xmath152 .",
    "[ prop : bij_fc_elements_heaps ] the map @xmath129 induces a bijection between @xmath18 and the set of @xmath104-heaps which satisfy ( h1 ) and ( h2 ) .",
    "moreover @xmath153 , and the reduced expressions for @xmath7 correspond bijectively to linear extensions of @xmath154 .",
    "the proof uses lemma  [ lem : fccommclasses ] : ( h1 ) ensures that the linear extensions of @xmath155 have no occurrence of @xmath114 , while ( h2 ) prevents linear extensions of @xmath121 to contain a braid word as a factor .    a @xmath104-heap satisfying ( h1 ) and ( h2 )",
    "will be called a _",
    "fc heap_. given a @xmath104-heap @xmath121 , denote by @xmath156 the subset of @xmath1 formed by the labels of the maximal elements of @xmath1 .",

    "in this section we will prove theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] , which states that @xmath16 is a rational series for any coxeter system @xmath56 .",
    "the fundamental tool we use is the concept of language recognized by a finite automaton , which we recall in the first paragraph .",
    "we refer to the book  @xcite for a general reference on the theory of automata .",
    "we only need the most basic notions .",
    "a _ finite , deterministic , complete automaton @xmath161 _ on the alphabet @xmath1 is the datum @xmath162 of a finite set of _ states _",
    "@xmath163 , a transition function @xmath164 , an initial state @xmath165 , and a subset @xmath166 of final states .",
    "the function @xmath167 is extended to @xmath168 by defining recursively @xmath169 and @xmath170 .",
    "we identify the automaton @xmath161 with its associated labeled multigraph with vertex set @xmath163 and oriented , labeled edges @xmath171 whenever @xmath172 ; see figure  [ fig : petitautomate ] for an example in which the final states are @xmath173 and @xmath174 .    .",
    "[ fig : petitautomate ] ]    the language @xmath175 recognized by the automaton @xmath161 is the set of words @xmath176 such that @xmath177 . in the graph , @xmath175 corresponds to the set of _ successful paths _ which are the paths going from @xmath173 to a state @xmath178 . in the example of figure  [ fig : petitautomate ]",
    ", the automaton recognizes the language of all words on @xmath179 such that the number of occurrences of @xmath180 is congruent to @xmath181 or @xmath180 modulo @xmath182 .",
    "languages which can be recognized by a finite automaton are called _",
    "regular_. regular languages are closed under complementation and intersection . in general",
    "they are known to coincide with the class of so - called rational languages ; this is a famous theorem of kleene .",
    "[ prop : regulartoseries ] the length generating function of a regular language is a rational series .",
    "let us sketch a proof of this well - known fact . given a regular language @xmath175 ,",
    "consider the matrix @xmath183 where @xmath184 is the number of oriented edges from @xmath185 to @xmath186 in the graphic representation of @xmath161 ( _ i.e. _ the number of @xmath158 such that @xmath172 ) .",
    "then the entry @xmath187 in the matrix @xmath188 is the length generating functions of all paths from @xmath185 to @xmath186 .",
    "thanks to the adjugate matrix formula , this entry is a rational function in @xmath45 with @xmath189 . to obtain the length generating function of @xmath175 , we notice that it is the sum of @xmath190 for @xmath178 , so it is also a rational function with denominator @xmath189 .    as a consequence of the proof , notice that the degree of the denominator of the rational function is not larger than the number of states of @xmath161 .      for the rest of this chapter , we fix a coxeter system @xmath56 with graph @xmath191",
    "in this paragraph , we shall define an automaton @xmath192 who recognizes the set of reduced words of fc elements in @xmath56 .",
    "the main question for designing such an automaton is the following : given such a word @xmath193 , what information is enough to ensure that @xmath194 is a reduced fc word ?",
    "first it is clear that this only depends on the element @xmath7 represented by @xmath109 .",
    "lemma  [ lem : fccommclasses ] tells us that we should consider the commutation class of @xmath194 and check that it contains no square @xmath114 or braid word . in terms of heaps ,",
    "we need to check that @xmath195 is a fc heap , i.e. the conditions form proposition  [ prop : bij_fc_elements_heaps ] hold .    before stating the main definition ,",
    "notice that if @xmath7 is a fc element and @xmath196 is any word , then we can define without ambiguity @xmath197 as the commutation class @xmath198 where @xmath109 is any reduced expression for @xmath7 .",
    "the heap @xmath199 is defined similarly .",
    "[ defi : qe ] let @xmath7 be a fc element with heap @xmath121 , and @xmath11 be such that @xmath200 .",
    "we define @xmath201 to be the word @xmath202_{r}}\\in s^*$ ] which is maximal among alternating suffixes of the chain @xmath203 such that @xmath204_{m_{st}-r}})$ ] contains an element with a factor @xmath113_{m_{st}}}$ ] or @xmath205_{m_{st}}}$ ] .",
    "equivalently , @xmath206 is chosen maximal so that @xmath207_{m_{st}-r}})$ ] contains a convex , alternating @xmath208-chain of length @xmath82 .",
    "it is important to note that @xmath209 need not occur as a suffix of any reduced word for @xmath7 . indeed , consider the fc element @xmath210 in type @xmath211 , i.e. with braid relations @xmath212 .",
    "then @xmath213 as is easily checked .",
    "define @xmath214 where @xmath215 runs through all edges with finite label .",
    "we represent @xmath216 by a diagram as follows : we start from @xmath217 and keep only its edge labels equal to @xmath218 . for all other edges @xmath215 , if @xmath219_{r}}$ ] with @xmath220 , then we orient @xmath215 towards @xmath45 and label it with @xmath206 ; if @xmath221 we leave the edge unlabeled and unoriented .",
    "[ ex : w0state ] consider the coxeter graph @xmath222 from example  [ ex : coxetergraph ] , and the fc element @xmath139 whose heap is @xmath141 on the right of figure  [ fig : heaps ] .",
    "then @xmath223 and @xmath224 , which we represent by the diagram .",

    "the important cases of the definition of the transition function are illustrated in figure  [ fig : transitions ] , where we use diagrams to represent @xmath225 as explained for @xmath216 above .",

    "suppose @xmath243 , say @xmath237",
    ". 1 .   if @xmath238_{k}}$ ] , @xmath244 , then @xmath245_{k+1}}$].[it : up2 ] 2 .",
    "if @xmath246_{k}$ ] , @xmath247 then @xmath248.[it : up3 ] 3 .",
    "suppose @xmath249 and is adjacent to both endpoints of @xmath215 , then @xmath250.[it : up4 ] 4 .",
    "[ it : up56 ] suppose @xmath44 is adjacent to exactly one endpoint of @xmath251 , say @xmath45 . 1 .   if @xmath252_{k}}$ ] , @xmath253 then set @xmath254 if @xmath255 while @xmath250 if @xmath256.[it : up5 ] 2 .   if @xmath257_{k}}$ ] , @xmath244 , then set @xmath250 if @xmath258 while @xmath259_{m_{st}-1}}$ ] if @xmath260.[it : up6 ]    a state @xmath185 is called _ accessible _ if there is a word @xmath109 such that @xmath261 .",
    "obviously the language defined by an automaton is not modified if only its accessible states are kept .",
    "[ defi : ared ] given a coxeter system @xmath56 , define the automaton @xmath20 on the alphabet @xmath1 to be the the automaton defined above restricted to its accessible states .    .",
    "the oriented edge is the one being modified , while the letter @xmath44 to be read is depicted with a small blue arrow .",
    "[ fig : transitions ] ]    for instance , the automaton recognizing @xmath262 is illustrated in figure  [ fig : autredw0 ] .",
    "it has @xmath263 states ; the sink state is not represented in the picture .     recognizing the language @xmath262 .",
    "all states are final ( the sink is not represented . ) [ fig : autredw0],scaledwidth=90.0% ]    let us mention two special cases of the automata @xmath192 .    if @xmath217 has no finite edges , then @xmath19 consists of words that have no squares @xmath114 in elements of their commutation class .",
    "it is easily seen that the knowledge of maxima of the heaps of @xmath19 is enough to recognize the language , which is precisely what @xmath20 does in this case .",
    "if @xmath217 is a complete graph , so that no commutations are possible , then elements of @xmath18 are precisely the elements of @xmath0 which have only one reduced expression .",
    "it is then easy to show that @xmath20 recognizes @xmath19 : note in particular that transitions of type   never occur .",
    "in fact it is true in general that for any @xmath56 , the reduced words for those elements of @xmath0 with a unique reduced expression form a regular language  @xcite .",
    "the core of this section is the following lemma :    [ lem : technical ] let @xmath109 be a word in @xmath105 and denote by @xmath121 its heap @xmath264 .",
    "+ @xmath60 if @xmath121 is not a fc heap , then @xmath265 .",
    "+ @xmath60 if @xmath121 is a fc heap , then @xmath266 where @xmath267 and @xmath268 for any edge @xmath215 with @xmath269 .",
    "we postpone the proof until section  [ sub : prooflemma ] , and state the main result of this section .",
    "[ th : reducedfcregular ] let @xmath56 be a coxeter system .",
    "then the language @xmath19 is recognized by @xmath20 .    by lemma  [ lem : technical ] , a word @xmath109",
    "is recognized by the automaton @xmath192 if and only if its heap is a fc heap .",
    "but this is the case precisely if @xmath109 is a reduced expression for a fc element , which completes the proof .",
    "before we show how to go from reduced expressions to elements , we make two remarks .",
    "[ rem : canaut ] recall that the complete set of reduced words @xmath270 is also known to be regular , see  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 4.8.3 ) .",
    "the automaton @xmath271 recognizing it uses the standard geometric representation of @xmath0 and properties of the associated roots : the key is that the set of so - called small roots is finite , and the states of @xmath271 are subsets of small roots . now in all the cases we computed , it seems that @xmath271 is a larger automaton than @xmath20 .",
    "it is then natural to wonder if some sub - automaton of @xmath271 actually recognize the subset @xmath19 of @xmath270 .",
    "more precisely , does there exist a subset of the edges of @xmath271 such that the successful paths avoiding these edges correspond precisely to the elements of @xmath19 ?",
    "[ rem : minimality ] automata theory tells us there exists a unique automaton with the smallest number of states recognizing a regular language @xmath272 , the _ minimal automaton _ of @xmath272 .",
    "this question is investigated in  @xcite for the language @xmath270 and the automaton @xmath271 mentioned in remark  [ rem : canaut ] .",
    "we can ask the same question regarding @xmath19 . some limited computer experimentations ( cf .",
    "remark  [ rem : implementation ] ) tend to show that @xmath20 is always close to being minimal , and minimal in numerous cases .",
    "we showed that reduced words of fc elements form a regular language .",
    "we are now interested in fc elements of @xmath0 themselves , and our strategy will be to pick for each @xmath47 a reduced word of @xmath7 ( thus having @xmath9 letters ) in order to obtain a regular language .    for the rest of this section we fix a total order @xmath273 of @xmath1 , which induces the lexicographical order on @xmath105 :",
    "@xmath274 if either @xmath275 is a strict prefix of @xmath276 or @xmath277 , @xmath278 and @xmath279 in @xmath1 . for each @xmath5",
    "we let @xmath280 be the lexicographically smallest element of @xmath98 .",
    "we finally define @xmath281 .",
    "[ th : wfcregular ] for any coxeter system @xmath56 and any total order @xmath273 on @xmath1 , the language @xmath282 is regular .",
    "theorem  [ th : rationality ] is an immediate corollary by using proposition  [ prop : regulartoseries ] and the fact that @xmath282 has generating function @xmath16 .",
    "associate to each @xmath107-commutation class @xmath283 its lexicographically minimal element @xmath284 , and let @xmath285 be the language of all @xmath286 .",
    "we claim that @xmath287 .",
    "indeed @xmath282 is clearly included in this intersection .",
    "now take a reduced word @xmath109 in @xmath19 , so it represents an element @xmath288 for which @xmath98 is a @xmath107-commutation class .",
    "if @xmath289 , then @xmath290 and thus is in @xmath282 , which proves the claim .",
    "now by a result of anisimov and knuth  @xcite , the language @xmath285 can be represented by a rational expression ; by the celebrated theorem of kleene , this means that @xmath285 is a regular language . since @xmath19 is regular by theorem  [ th : reducedfcregular ] ,",
    "we have written @xmath282 as the intersection of two regular languages , and so it is itself regular .    in the previous proof",
    ", one can replace @xmath285 by the language @xmath291 obtained by picking for each @xmath5 the lexicographically smallest reduced expression of @xmath7 .",
    "indeed it was proved in  @xcite that @xmath291 is a regular language , and clearly @xmath292 .",
    "however the proof that it is regular is much more complicated than for @xmath285 .",
    "[ rem : implementation ] we were able to fully implement the computation of @xmath16 : given a coxeter graph @xmath217 , our program outputs a rational function @xmath293 representing @xmath16 .",
    "it was done in sage  @xcite using the module on automata .",
    "the implementation follows closely the proof of theorem  [ th : rationality ] .",
    "first , one constructs the automaton @xmath20 recognizing @xmath19 , by using the definition of @xmath167 to construct the states and transitions inductively .",
    "then , one constructs the automaton recognizing @xmath285 , via a nondeterministic automaton recognizing @xmath294 built using the result of  @xcite .",
    "then the product automaton recognizing @xmath295 is constructed , and from this one can compute the desired rational function as sketched in the proof of proposition  [ prop : regulartoseries ] .",
    "the proof goes by induction on the length of @xmath109 .",
    "it is obviously true for @xmath296 by definition of @xmath297 .",
    "now we assume the claim holds for a word @xmath109 , and we will show it for @xmath298 where @xmath44 is any letter .",
    "we shall denote by @xmath121 and @xmath128 the heaps of the words @xmath109 and @xmath196 respectively .",
    "@xmath60 assume first that @xmath128 is not a fc heap .",
    "if @xmath121 is not fc either , then by induction @xmath299 so that @xmath300 by   as wanted .",

    "if no endpoint of @xmath215 is adjacent to @xmath44 , then @xmath308 has no influence on the convexity of the chain @xmath314 and so @xmath315 .",

    "the remaining case is when @xmath44 is adjacent to one endpoint of @xmath215 , say @xmath251 and @xmath44 is adjacent to @xmath45 and not to @xmath322 . 1 .",
    "if @xmath323_{k}}$ ] then , when @xmath324 , the addition of @xmath308 will prevent the extension of @xmath320 , since any later addition of @xmath45 will make the corresponding chain non convex . from this",
    "we get that if @xmath325 , then @xmath326 so @xmath327 ; if @xmath325 then @xmath321 2 .   if @xmath323_{k}}$ ] , then the corresponding convex alternating chain in @xmath128 can be extended by one @xmath45-element .",
    "however it can not be extended by two elements ( labeled @xmath45 and @xmath322 ) because @xmath308 then prevents convexity .",
    "if @xmath328 we get @xmath315 , while if @xmath329 we are reduced to @xmath321 .    by inspection , we have indeed @xmath330 in all cases , which completes the induction step , and the proof of lemma  [ lem : technical ] .",
    "in this section we classify coxeter groups @xmath0 whose associated fc length counting sequence @xmath331 is ultimately periodic ; we call _ fc - periodic _ such a group .",
    "this is a natural extension of stembridge s result  @xcite who classified _ fc - finite _ coxeter groups , _",
    "i.e. _ with a _ finite _ number of fc elements : the result is the family ( pf ) , illustrated in figure  [ fig : fc_periodic_graphs ] .    we can focus on irreducible groups , thanks to the following lemma .",
    "let @xmath332 be written as a product of irreducible coxeter groups .",
    "then @xmath0 is fc - periodic iff all factors @xmath333 are fc - finite except possibly one of them which is fc - periodic .",
    "the proof follows easily from the easy decomposition @xmath334 .",
    "thanks to this lemma , we focus on irreducible groups from now on .",
    "consider the family @xmath335 of irreducible coxeter groups given by the union of the following three families , see figure  [ fig : fc_periodic_graphs ] :    1 .",
    "[ fam1 ] irreducible fc - finite coxeter groups ; 2 .",
    "[ fam2 ] irreducible affine coxeter groups different from @xmath336 and @xmath337 ; 3 .",
    "[ fam3 ] exceptional groups of types @xmath23 and @xmath24 .",
    "the affine types @xmath336 and @xmath337 are excluded from ( pa ) since they already occur in ( pe ) under the names @xmath338 and @xmath339 .",
    "note that the index for a family in ( pf ) gives the number of generators of @xmath0 , while in ( pa ) it corresponds to this number minus one .    .",
    "[ fig : fc_periodic_graphs ] ]    we can now restate theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] .",
    "[ th : classification ] let @xmath0 be an irreducible coxeter group . then @xmath0 is fc - periodic if and only if @xmath0 has type in @xmath340 .",
    "if @xmath0 is not fc - periodic , then @xmath341 grows exponentially fast .",
    "one implication in this theorem follows from the following result .",
    "[ prop : periodic_families ] if @xmath0 has type in @xmath340 , then @xmath0 is fc - periodic .",
    "this is obvious for elements of ( pf ) , since the sequence is ultimately constant equal to @xmath181 .",
    "the fact that all elements of ( pa ) are fc - periodic is the main results of @xcite .",
    "for the two remaining types @xmath23 and @xmath24 of ( pe ) , there are two ways to show fc - periodicity . the first one , which we only sketch , is to do as for exceptional affine coxeter groups in  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 5.2 ) : one must examine the structure of the corresponding fc heaps closely , and observe that a certain pattern repeats itself periodically when the size is large enough .",
    "the case of @xmath23 can be treated as @xmath342 in  @xcite , while the case of @xmath343 is slightly more involved .",
    "the second way is to take advantage of the results of section  [ sec : rationality ] , which allows us to exhibit the rational generating function @xmath16 , see remark  [ rem : implementation ] . for @xmath23 ,",
    "the generating function has the form @xmath344 and so we get a period @xmath345 when the length is large enough . in the case of @xmath24 ,",
    "one gets a denominator reduced to @xmath346 : the growth function is ultimately constant , and is in fact equal to @xmath347 for any length @xmath348 .",
    "it remains to prove that for any type not in @xmath340 , the growth sequence increases exponentially fast .",
    "to do this we first obtain a technical result which will allow us to focus on certain minimal types .    given two coxeter graphs @xmath349 , write @xmath350 if @xmath64 is isomorphic ( as an unlabelled graph ) to a subgraph @xmath351 of @xmath121 ( not necessarily induced ) such that the edge labels of @xmath64 are less than or equal to those of @xmath351 .",
    "[ lemma : monotony ] let @xmath352 be irreducible coxeter groups with graphs @xmath353 satisfying @xmath354 .",
    "then @xmath355 for all @xmath356 .    by hypothesis",
    ", we have an injective morphism from @xmath357 to @xmath358 so we can safely assume that @xmath359 and that the morphism is the identity on @xmath357 .",
    "notice that @xmath354 then means precisely that @xmath360 for all @xmath361 .",
    "let @xmath7 be any element in @xmath362 .",
    "its set of reduced words @xmath363 is a @xmath364-commutation class of words on @xmath365 of length @xmath8 . by hypothesis @xmath366",
    "implies @xmath367 for any @xmath361 , which shows that @xmath111 is a union of @xmath368-commutation classes .",
    "pick one such @xmath368-commutation class @xmath369 , and consider @xmath370 .",
    "then @xmath109 has no squares @xmath114 , since @xmath371 and thus is a reduced word for @xmath372 . now consider @xmath361 such that @xmath373 .",
    "if @xmath374 , then no braid word @xmath375_{m^{(1)}_{st}}}$ ] occurs in @xmath109 and so _ a fortiori _ no braid word @xmath375_{m^{(2)}_{st}}}$ ] occurs either . if @xmath367 , then no braid factor @xmath375_{m^{(2)}_{st}}}$ ] can occur in @xmath109 since it",
    "would then fail to be reduced for @xmath364 .",
    "we showed that @xmath376 is a fc commutation class for @xmath368 , and so corresponds to an element in @xmath377 by lemma  [ lem : fccommclasses ] .",
    "the map @xmath378 is therefore an injection from @xmath362 to @xmath379 .",
    "let @xmath64 be a coxeter graph which is not in any of the families ( pf ) , ( pa ) or ( pe ) .",
    "we will first determine all such graphs which are minimal for the order @xmath380 introduced above .",
    "denote by @xmath381 the family of coxeter graphs depicted in figure  [ fig : minimal_graphs ] .     the family @xmath381 of coxeter graphs",
    ". types @xmath382 and @xmath383 are defined for @xmath384 , and types @xmath385 for @xmath386 . , scaledwidth=90.0% ]    [ lemma : mingraphs ] if @xmath64 is a connected coxeter graph not in @xmath340 , then there exists @xmath387 such that @xmath388 .",
    "_ case @xmath180 : @xmath64 contains a cycle_. pick a minimal cycle in @xmath64 .",
    "since @xmath389 , one has @xmath390 or @xmath391 for a certain @xmath384 , and we are done in this case .    from now on , we assume that @xmath64 has no cycle , i.e. @xmath64 is a tree .",
    "_ case @xmath392 : @xmath64 contains an edge label @xmath393_. let @xmath394 be an edge with label @xmath395 . since @xmath396 , @xmath64 has at least three vertices .",
    "if @xmath64 has exactly three vertices , then since @xmath397 , we have @xmath398 or @xmath399 . if neither @xmath322 nor @xmath310 is a leaf , then @xmath400 . if @xmath322 or @xmath310 has degree @xmath401 , then @xmath402 .",
    "there remains the case where @xmath64 has vertices @xmath403 with edges @xmath404 and @xmath405 .",
    "if @xmath406 , then @xmath407 . if @xmath408 , @xmath409 implies @xmath410 or @xmath411 for a certain @xmath412 .",
    "_ case @xmath182 : @xmath64 has maximal edge label @xmath57 . _",
    "assume first that the label @xmath57 occurs at least twice , and pick two edges labeled @xmath57 with simple edges on the path linking them .",
    "since @xmath413 , there is an edge in @xmath64 not on this path ; depending on the position of this edge one gets @xmath414 for @xmath415 or @xmath416 , @xmath417 .",
    "now suppose @xmath64 has exactly one edge @xmath394 labeled @xmath57 . if @xmath64 has no branch point , then since @xmath418 , one has necessarily @xmath419 .",
    "if @xmath64 has a branch point of degree @xmath420 , one has @xmath417 or @xmath421 for a certain @xmath386 ; if the branch point has degree @xmath182 , then since @xmath422 one has @xmath423 or @xmath424 for a certain @xmath386 .",
    "_ case @xmath57 : @xmath64 has all edge labels equal to @xmath182 . _ since @xmath425 , @xmath64 has necessarily at least one branch point , _ i.e. _ a vertex of degree larger than @xmath392 . if @xmath64 has two branch points or more , then since @xmath426 one has @xmath421 for an @xmath386 .",
    "we may now assume @xmath64 has exactly one branch point , say of degree @xmath55 .",
    "if @xmath427 , then @xmath428 . if @xmath429 , then since @xmath430 one has @xmath431 . if @xmath432 , then since @xmath433 one has necessarily @xmath434 or @xmath435",
    ".    this completes the proof .",
    "[ lemma : unboundedgraphs ] for each coxeter group @xmath0 with type in @xmath381 , the sequence @xmath436 grows exponentially .",
    "let us first deal with the exceptional cases @xmath437 , @xmath438 .",
    "it is possible in each case to prove the non - boundedness directly , by coming up with specific fc elements or heaps .",
    "for instance , in the case of @xmath439 , @xmath440 and @xmath441 are fc elements , and one checks that all possible products of @xmath442 and @xmath443 are reduced and form distinct elements of @xmath18 .",
    "we rather proceed as in proposition  [ prop : periodic_families ] , by using the results of section  [ sec : rationality ] and our implementation mentioned in remark  [ rem : implementation ] .",
    "this gives us the rational generating functions @xmath444 , whose denominators we recorded in figure  [ tb : minina ] . in each case",
    ", there is a positive root smaller than @xmath180 , which forces an exponential growth for @xmath445 .",
    "@xmath446    in type @xmath382 , define the words @xmath447 and @xmath448 . now consider the set @xmath116 of words of the form @xmath449 , where @xmath450 , @xmath451 if @xmath452 , @xmath453 if @xmath454 while @xmath455 if @xmath456 . notice that these words in @xmath116 have no adjacent commuting letters , and no braid factor .",
    "@xmath116 can be naturally considered as a subset of @xmath18 which grows exponentially , and this proves the claim in type @xmath382 .    in type @xmath383 ,",
    "let @xmath109 be the word @xmath457 .",
    "now consider the set @xmath458 of words @xmath459 , where @xmath460 is either @xmath461 or @xmath462 .",
    "these are all reduced words for distinct fc elements ( notice that the only possible commutations involve the letters @xmath462 ) .",
    "so @xmath458 clearly corresponds to a family in @xmath18 with exponential growth .",
    "finally , one notices that types @xmath385 resemble types @xmath463 . in  @xcite",
    ", it was shown that these were fc - finite , and in fact the corresponding fc heaps were entirely classified . in particular there were two infinite families , alternating and _ zigzag _ heaps .",
    "zigzag heaps are given by words occurring as factors of @xmath464 in type @xmath465 .",
    "we now fix a zigzag element @xmath7 of type @xmath465 with heap @xmath121 .",
    "we describe how to obtain a family of fc elements in type @xmath466 for @xmath467 and @xmath416 :    1 .",
    "insert @xmath322-elements such that , in the word @xmath468 , these occurrences are always separated by at least one @xmath469 .",
    "insert @xmath470-elements so that in the word @xmath471 , these occurrences are always separated by at least two @xmath472 s .",
    "3 .   change all occurrences of @xmath322 by @xmath473 to get a word with heap @xmath128 . then insert @xmath470-elements so that in the word @xmath474 , these occurrences are always separated by at least two @xmath472 .    in each case , one verifies that the heaps created are indeed fc heaps .",
    "also , when the initial zigzag element increases in length , more and more heaps are created .",
    "this shows that in each type the heaps created determine a family that grows exponentially with length . the case @xmath475",
    "are dealt with in the same manner by replacing occurrences of @xmath45 by @xmath476 in the resulting heaps .",
    "we can now conclude the proof of theorem  [ th : classification ] . by proposition  [ prop : periodic_families ] ,",
    "all graphs in @xmath340 are fc - periodic .",
    "let @xmath104 be a coxeter graph which is not in @xmath340 .",
    "by lemma  [ lemma : mingraphs ] , there exists @xmath477 with @xmath478 .",
    "the counting sequence of fc elements of @xmath479 is exponential by lemma  [ lemma : unboundedgraphs ] , so by lemma  [ lemma : monotony ] the counting sequence of fc elements of @xmath104 also is , which completes the proof .",
    "we now give some possible continuations for this work ; some of them were mentioned in the course of the text .",
    "there are several questions of interest regarding our automaton @xmath20 recognizing @xmath19 . for various families of coxeter groups , for instance finite and affine types",
    ", one could look at the combinatorics of the states of @xmath20 , by studying their structure , enumerate them , etc . on a related note , and",
    "as mentioned in remark  [ rem : minimality ] , it would be interesting to study questions of minimality .",
    "also , @xmath20 is defined in an _ ad hoc _ manner requiring in particular a technical disjunction of cases . in remark",
    "[ rem : canaut ] , we raised the question of designing another automaton recognizing @xmath19 based on the pre - existing automaton @xmath271 recognizing all @xmath270 .",
    "as for the classification result given in theorem  [ th : classification_intro ] , it would be interesting to find a uniform explanation for the periodic behaviour ; this question was already asked in  @xcite for affine types .",
    "when @xmath18 grows exponentially on the other hand , it is natural to wonder if there is a `` gap '' in the exponential rates of growth : if @xmath480 is defined by @xmath481 , are the @xmath480 bounded away from @xmath180 when @xmath0 runs through non fc - periodic irreducible coxeter groups ?",
    "note that , as a byproduct of our proof , it is enough to study this question for the groups in @xmath381 , see figure  [ fig : minimal_graphs ] .",
    "h.  n.  v. temperley and e.  h. lieb",
    ". relations between the `` percolation '' and `` colouring '' problem and other graph - theoretical problems associated with regular planar lattices : some exact results for the `` percolation '' problem . , 322(1549):251280 , 1971 .",
    "g.  x. viennot .",
    "heaps of pieces .",
    "i. basic definitions and combinatorial lemmas . in _",
    "combinatoire numrative ( montreal , que . , 1985/quebec , que . , 1985",
    ") _ , volume 1234 of _ lecture notes in math .",
    "_ , pages 321350 .",
    "springer , berlin , 1986 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in a coxeter group @xmath0 , an element is _ fully commutative _ if any two of its reduced expressions can be linked by a series of commutation of adjacent letters . </S>",
    "<S> these elements have particularly nice combinatorial properties , and also index a basis of the generalized temperley  </S>",
    "<S> lieb algebra attached to @xmath0 .    </S>",
    "<S> we give two results about the sequence counting these elements with respect to their coxeter length . </S>",
    "<S> first we prove that it always satisfies a linear recurrence with constant coefficients , by showing that reduced expressions of fully commutative elements form a regular language . </S>",
    "<S> then we classify those groups @xmath0 for which the sequence is ultimately periodic , extending a result of stembridge . </S>",
    "<S> these results are applied to the growth of generalized temperley  lieb algebras . </S>"
  ]
}
